answers: The Spanish Tragedy, or Hieronimo is Mad Again
parts: This contemporary of Shakespeare was considered at the time to be the foremost tragedian. This man, who wrote Doctor Faustus, died a mysterious early death, leading some to believe he was the one who wrote Shakespeare’s plays.
The dramatist Thomas Kyd wrote this revenge play about Hieronimo avenging his dead son, Balthazar. Elements from this play are thought to have inspired parts of Hamlet.

The poet Edmund Spenser wrote this epic poem, an allegory celebrating the reign of Elizabeth I. Characters including the Redcrosse Knight and Britomart represent different Christian ideals in this work.
Name this empire that considered itself the rightful heir to Rome. It is also commonly known as the Eastern Roman Empire.
This emperor with the epithet “the great” ruled the Byzantine Empire and built the Hagia Sophia. His namesake code was a revision of Roman law.
Justinian sent this general to conquer Ravenna from the Ostrogoths. He was called out of retirement to fight the Bulgars at the Battle of Melantias.
This country is the world’s largest Muslim majority country by population. Many Muslims worship at Istiqlal Mosque in its capital of Jakarta.
These nomadic people of North Africa live in tent communities that are each led by a jama’ah. The Tuareg Confederation of these people temporarily created a breakaway state in Mali known as Azawad.
These people of western China live in the state of Xinjiang. A so-called “leader” of them, Rebiya Kadeer, seeks to establish the state of East Turkestan for them.
Name these materials whose atoms are arranged in a highly ordered structure. They form a namesake lattice, and examples of this type of material include snowflakes and diamonds.
Materials described by this adjective are considered the opposite of crystals, as they lack long range order.
This type of crystallography can be used to find the structure of crystals. It was used by Rosalind Franklin to find the structure of DNA.
This tone poem composed by Jean Sibelius was performed under alternate names in order to escape Russian censorship; one such name was A Scandinavian Choral March.

This Hungarian composer included many folk elements in his music, especially seen in his Hungarian Folk Song collection. He is better known for his opera Duke Bluebeard’s Castle and, ironically, his collection of Romanian Folk Dances.
This Czech composer wrote a set of symphonic poems titled Má vlast, meaning “My Homeland,” he also wrote a string quartet titled From My Life after his daughter died.

answers: End of the world [accept common knowledge equivalents]
Branch Davidians [prompt on “Davidians”; accept The Branch]
parts: This broad term refers to small organizations with practices considered to be fringe; notable examples include Aum Shinrikyo in Japan and Heaven’s Gate in the United States.
Those two aforementioned groups are classified by the term millenarian because they believe this event is coming.

A prominent doomsday cult was this group, which believed David Koresh was a prophet. Many members died during a 1993 F.B.I. and A.T.F. siege to the Mount Carmel Center in Waco, Texas, after a building caught fire.
Name this architect who built a chapel in Ronchamp, France, known as the Notre Dame du Haut. This man used his “five points of architecture” when designing his most renowned building.
Probably Le Corbusier’s most famous work is this house located on the outskirts of Paris. With a solely white facade, this building’s upper level is supported by several pilotis.
Le Corbusier designed the Open Hand Monument for a city in this country. Constantin Brancusi was supposed to design a temple for the Maharajah of Indore in this country, but it was never completed.

answers: Li Bai [accept Li Po or Li Bo]
parts: Name this Chinese poet of “Quiet Night Thought.” He also claimed, “I drink alone, for no friend is near” in “Drinking Alone by Moonlight.”
In one poem written by Li Bai, the speaker admires one of these objects at Lushan Mountain, which he compares to “the Milky Way falling from Ninth Heaven.”
Li Bai, along with his poet friend Du Fu, lived during this Chinese dynasty, which saw a flourishing of culture.
Name these early arthropods that serve as useful fossils and are named for their three-lobed bodies.
Trilobites flourished in this era that preceded the Mesozoic Era. Its name means ancient life.
The extinction following the end of the Paleozoic led to the release of this compound from a namesake clathrate.
Name this Athenian historian of the Peloponnesian War whose definitive account rails against the anecdotal methodology of Herodotus. He would be exiled after being scapegoated for a military defeat.
This Athenian admiral who commanded the Sicilian Expedition advocated for an aggressive foreign policy. He too would flee Athens after being the victim of political persecution.
The Peloponnesian War was fought between Athens and this long-time rival city-state. Just half a century earlier, three hundred of its soldiers stood against Persia at Thermopylae.
The Yoruba people of this continent believe in a pantheon of gods with stories as rich as the Greco-Roman tradition. In Christian legend, the Queen of Sheba is from this continent.

The chief god of Olorun founded the city of Ile-Ife after sending Obtala to earth with a snail shell in order to perform this action. By some accounts, Obtala was accompanied by a pigeon and a hen that helped him with this process.

Another West African tradition reveres this trickster god who often takes the form of a spider. He became the god of storytelling after capturing a python, leopard, and swarm of hornets for the sky-god Nyame.

This Alabama governor famously declared “Segregation now, segregation tomorrow, segregation forever.” He also prevented two African-American students from entering the University of Alabama in the “Stand in the Schoolhouse Door.”

This city’s police commissioner, “Bull” Connor, used police dogs to attack Freedom Riders entering it. The KKK bombed 16th Street Baptist Church in this most populous city of Alabama, killing four girls.
This field secretary of the NAACP was assassinated by Byron De La Beckwith in 1963. He fought for the integration of the University of Mississippi.
Name this Erskine Caldwell novel whose protagonist, Jeeter Lester, has a deathly fear of rats.
Tobacco Road is set several miles outside of the city of Augusta in this state that is also the setting of The Heart is a Lonely Hunter.
Also set in Georgia, this Margaret Mitchell novel focuses on Scarlett O’Hara and takes place on the plantation known as Tara.

This franchise developed by FromSoftware and published by Namco Bandai is known for its challenging bosses including Ornstein and Smough [Sm-OWW] and the Asylum Demon. This specific franchise came after its “Demons’” counterpart.

This franchise, whose first home installments were released on the Nintendo Entertainment System, features the ninja Ryu Hayabusa. Developers for this game include Tecmo and, more recently, Team Ninja.

This franchise, developed by Rare, follows the title amphibians in their various escapades. An old prank involving this game revolves around calling a GameStop to preorder nonsensical editions of this game.
Cystic fibrosis most commonly affects the lungs, but the disorder can also affect these bean-shaped organs that filter the blood to make urine.
As a result of lung infections caused by CF, individuals with the disease often cough up this substance that is produced in goblet cells in the nose.
Because CF results when neither copy of the allele for the CFTR gene is working, cystic fibrosis is considered this kind of genetic disorder.

The rules of this genre, which discusses human suffering and is the opposite of comedy, were first established by Aeschylus in plays such as the Oresteia, Seven Against Thebes, and The Libation Bearers.
One of the three Greek tragedians, Sophocles, wrote this play about the title character’s joint attempts to avenge the death of her father, Agamemnon, at the hands of her mother Clytemnestra.
If Aeschylus was the father of tragedy, this Athenian playwright was the father of comedy. He wrote several plays whose titles were derived from animals, such as The Wasps and The Birds.

answers: Classical Conditioning [prompt on “Conditioning”; do NOT accept “Operant conditioning”]
parts: Name this learning principle made famous by Pavlov’s dogs, where a biological stimulus and neutral stimulus are paired such that the two become associated and trigger responses to the other.
Classical and operant conditioning make up the theoretical foundations of this twentieth century psychological school of thought that was notably propounded by thinkers like John Watson.
This behaviorist articulated a vision of utopian society where scientific conditioning is used to perfect the human race in Walden Two, which described an experimental community led by T.E. Frazer.

This unit of length is most famous for its appearance in the title of a Jules Verne novel; in that context, it means three nautical miles. In its common usage, it was roughly the distance a man could walk in an hour.

A scientific unit named after this scientist is equal to the amount of time taken for light in a vacuum to travel a length of the same name, that length being the smallest meaningful distance in the universe.
This unit actually is metric, the quantification of illuminance. The American equivalent of this unit is the foot-candle, and it roughly corresponds to a meter-candle.

answers: War of the Triple Alliance [prompt on “Paraguayan War”]
President of the United States of America [prompt on “President”]
parts: Name this war, which saw Paraguay fighting for the province of Mato Grosso against a coalition of countries led by Bartolome Mitre, Pedro II, and Venancio Flores.

Paraguay was led by this dictator during the War of the Triple Alliance. He was killed at the Battle of Cerro Cora, and he ordered the killings of political officials and citizens in the San Fernando Massacres.

The largest department of Paraguay is named in honor of one of these people, who sided with it during negotiations to end the war. Another one of these people sent Richard Olney to mediate a border dispute between Venezuela and British Guiana.
Name this Dutch artist who coined the term neo-plasticism and painted such works as Composition II in Red, Blue, and Yellow.
In many works, such as Composition II in Red, Blue, and Yellow, perpendicular black lines are used to create these shapes.
Neo-plasticism was developed during and became synonymous with this abstract Dutch art movement.
